title: Reducing SSI Rates in Orthopedic Surgery
objective: To evaluate the impact of KRG Customized Orthopedic Packs on Surgical Site Infection (SSI) rates and intraoperative fluid management during Total Knee Replacement (TKR) procedures.
methodology: A retrospective study compared 120 TKR procedures using standard hospital-assembled kits with 120 procedures using KRG Medifabb's reinforced customized packs over a 12-month period.
outcomes: Achieved a 22% overall reduction in post-operative infection rates.
Eliminated intraoperative drape failure caused by fluid saturation through KRG's Heavy-Duty Fluid Collection Pouches.
Reduced OR setup personnel fatigue by consolidating 14 individual components into a single sterile barrier.

protocol.desc: Mapping existing theater workflow and component waste analysis.
Reinforced fluid collection pouches integrated for high-volume arthroplasty.
Phase-1 implementation across senior surgical teams.
Standardization of TKR packs across the orthopedic wing.

economicImpact: Estimated annual savings of ₹42,00,000 through reduced theater time and infection-related readmission costs.

title: Optimizing OR Turnover with Custom Packs
objective: Assessing the efficiency of 'Ready-to-Use' bespoke surgical packs in high-volume cardiac surgery theaters to increase daily procedure capacity.
methodology: Time-and-motion analysis of OR turnover phases across 5 departmental theaters over 6 months.
outcomes: Saved average of 18 minutes per setup by eliminating individual component peeling.
Standardized sterile field preparation across different surgical teams.
Significant reduction in 'Wait Time' for anesthesia induction due to faster tray preparation.

protocol.desc: Identifying time-bottlenecks in manual tray preparation.
Removing redundant secondary packaging from core drapes.
Syncing sterile supply chain with surgical schedules.
Rapid-setup walkthroughs for nursing and scrub staff.

economicImpact: Additional revenue generation through one extra high-value cardiac procedure per day per theater.

title: Sustainability in Disposable Management
objective: Reducing the environmental footprint of laparotomy procedures by optimizing component selection and material weight without compromising clinical safety.
methodology: Component auditing of standard lap-packs to identify redundant materials and high-volume waste items.
outcomes: Removed 4 redundant components previously included by legacy suppliers.
Switched to KRG's recycled-core polypropylene for non-critical barrier zones.
Reduced medical waste disposal costs by 28% year-on-year.

protocol.desc: Categorizing surgical waste by weight and material type.
Replacing multiple SKUs with a single streamlined solution.
Monthly ESG benchmarks provided to hospital board.

economicImpact: Documented reduction in clinical waste incineration costs and improved ESG rating for the hospital group.
